title: I am 16 years old. Is it too late to start learning piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: What?!! No, no, no, no! Not too late at ALL!! [By the way, I admit, I just answered this same Q for a 24-year old, so I’m “plagiarizing” myself somewhat—but not entirely, because that 8-year difference between you and the [also really great] 24-year-old may be of some importance in all this.]  This adult student is really great—and older than 16! [as, well, all adults are] Kiddo, what’s up? Okay, let’s do this: I’m a [very “young”—young-seeming <chuckle>] mid-40s person, and I’m “fit” and all—I do my running and swimming—but I’ve NEVER learned to snow-board, which I’ve really wanted to do since my mid-20s. Do you think it’s too late for this old granny-person [um, I’ve no grandkid really], sitting here typing, with my ancient mind wandering over, now and then, to ponder, “Hey, just WHEN will I get a senior’s citizen discount at the movies and for my swimming pass and all?—that’ll be great!” — oh, sorry, Young Person, where was I? Oh—do you think it’s too late for me, right in my mid-40s, to learn how to snow-board? [Answer key: No.] Just make sure you’re going to be taught [piano . . . . . not snow-boarding—well, maybe snow-boarding, too, but I don’t have a clue about that one yet] by someone who’s very experienced teaching folks your age, because you may be pretty miserable if you don’t take this advice—like you might feel ridiculous if you’re assigned things like Variations on ‘Twinkle, Twinkle,” or you may get someone who pulls some “adult piano method” book out, and you’ll be learning inane arrangements of stuff from, like, old musicals and—I don’t know—the Beach Boys or whoever. If you wish to play very casually, it may really not make a huge difference about how you go about learning—except you’ll learn much more quickly/efficiently and *well* from a [real—not video-taped or “online”] teacher who you’re quite sure knows what s/he’s doing. As for your progress, you older “kids” [sorry if you hate being called that—it’s just that your prefrontal cortext (in your brain) hasn’t developed nearly as much as it should to be an “adult” yet—that happens around age 25—really]—ANYway, older kids [“adolescents”] and young adults progress FAR more quickly than the younger kiddos do, particularly at first, because you will (most likely!) be better able to focus mindfully during your lessons, and you’ll better understand what you’re instructor could possibly be talking about! And, you’ll have more diligence to practice *in a way that will lead to quicker learning of your pieces*. (A lot of younger kids think that sitting down and just “playing through” stuff is good-enough practice, but you’ll know better. Just be sure to get a good teacher who will teach you this stuff.) That said, you’ll have to wait a bit—maybe 8-10 years—before you go applying to Yale School of Music or Julliard or CCM (Cincinnati) or any such place. And, if you want that, you’ll really have to work it, Aspiring Pianist! But, hey—if that’s what you’d love to do, do it. Get to it without delay, my young friend! Let me say, that sight-reading will likely always be more difficult for you than for younger-starting pianists. It just has to do with how the way the brain works—you know, all that stuff about “developmental stages” and all. SO, for mostly this reason, when you get to a solid intermediate level—and that may take as little as three years, give or take—anyway, you’ll very likely find that, then, you can’t keep up with the learning pace of someone who started reading music before s/he started reading words. Regardless of whether you start tomorrow or “sometime down the road,” in order to get to the point where you’re able to play, say, virtually anything by Brahms—or, like, for example, what I was playing last night, Mussorgsky’s Pictures at an Exhibition—you’ll likely find it starts becoming a little more “slow-going.” But, hey, a lot of the Mozart sonatas—beautiful works—you can get to, without too much frustration if you’re really serious! Let’s say you don’t want to go to some great conservatory/put-off-college-for- seven-or-eight-years: Okay. And, still, it would not surprise me a bit if, eventually, you get to the point (if it means a lot to you) where you could be quite skilled and become a recitalist or do chamber music with string (or other) players of your same general level. And, hey, playing that “really hard” stuff I mentioned above somewhere, may mean nothing much at all to you—and that’s completely understandable, because there’s TONS of literature that isn’t so difficult, but that’s absolutely beautiful. So, for example, I’d say, depending on your time and motivation, you could play those beautiful pieces by Erik Satie—his Gymnopédies and Gnossiennes—check those out on YouTube or whatnot—by perhaps your late-third year. And those are very REAL pieces! I played the Gnossiennes a few years ago, right along with Debussy’s Suite Bergamasque and—hmm—-SOMEthing by Ravel that I can’t think of right at this moment. If you’re more interested in pop “sheet music” and stuff, that will take not much time at all to learn. Go right for it, without doubt. (It’s just not my “thing” at all, but who cares, I say.) Okay—and if you’re not able to get those lessons anytime soon, don’t fret. Like, sometimes I [yes, a bit oddly, but it’s true], think, “Wow—wouldn’t it be great to have become a really cool graphic designer?!” So, if those piano lessons never, ever happened, I’d have found something I could enjoy a lot. And. so, you go forth and get those piano lessons whenever you can (and if possible, try not to wait much longer, okay?)—and if that doesn’t work out, just BE who you are, doing whatever you find that you can and that you can enjoy. (As long as it’s something that doesn’t hurt anyone — including you). Okay, sorry for the [really-typical-of-me] lengthy answer. Well, it’s good bedtime reading, as it will put you right to sleep! Sending you my best hopes! —Poppy Anthópolos

BEST13 EFFECTIVELY METHODS TO LEARN PIANO.. Question: #Is 16 too old to start learning music piano. Let me share best piano tips as below, I hope you enjoy it. 1. Set goals Know what you want to accomplish as a piano player. Do you want to perform for a special event, play for your own enjoyment, or learn a favorite song? Have a clear goal in mind of why you want to learn to play the piano. It will help keep you focused and motivated as well as give you something to work toward. 2. The Miyagi Technique The #1 technique for piano beginners is something Zack likes to call his Miyagi Technique, named after the infamous Mr. Miyagi on The Karate Kid. Using Zack’s technique, you’ll accomplish smoother tone, faster playing, and injury prevention. It’s one of the best warmup exercises for piano newbies and involves learning how to press each key to get the result you’re looking for. 3. Find a teacher There are plenty of online tutorials to help you teach yourself, but it is always good to have a teacher. Meeting regularly with a teacher can help you reach your goals and be accountable. It’s a good idea to have a support system of people encouraging you as you learn a new skill. Useful post: Top 10 frree and paid piano courses online 4. Learn the basics It’s important to start with the basics. If you don’t already know how to read music or the fundamentals of playing the piano, take time to learn notes, rhythm, scales, proper posture, and other basic skills. Failing to learn correct habits and good piano-playing practices now will hold you back later on. 5. Find music you enjoy playing Many people think that they must start by playing classical music. That is not always the case. If you want to play for fun and enjoyment, start with songs that you like. Pop songs are great to start with because they often have simple melodies and tunes that are easy to pick up. The key to enjoying playing the piano is to find music you enjoy learning to play. It will motivate you to keep learning, and it will be rewarding to successfully play a familiar tune. 6. Take it one step at a time It takes time to get used to playing a new instrument. Have patience with yourself if you can’t master a song as fast as you would like to. Keep trying and don’t give up. Start with songs that are at your current level and gradually challenge yourself to play harder songs as you progress. Know your limits, and pick songs that are at your level or slightly above your level. Don’t try to play a song that is too advanced. Don’t rush yourself—set a pace that you can maintain and that fits with your goals. 7. Be willing to make mistakes Mistakes are a part of learning. Don’t feel embarrassed if you make mistakes or if a song or skill is difficult for you to learn. Most piano teachers don’t mind if you make mistakes because it shows you are trying. They want to help you improve. When you make mistakes, it helps them understand what you are struggling with and how they can help you. 8. Celebrate improvements Remember where you started and celebrate your improvements, no matter how small. When you see the progress you’ve made, you will be more inclined to continue. When you’ve mastered a song or skill that was difficult, celebrate that accomplishment. Even if you aren’t a perfect pianist after taking lessons, you will be better and more knowledgeable than you were before you started. 9. Have fun Enjoy learning and doing something new. Having enthusiasm for learning is more important than having talent. You may not be a concert pianist or go on to perform in Carnegie Hall, but if you have fun playing and enjoy learning new songs, that will make your effort worth it. 10. Start now Don’t procrastinate learning to play the piano for another day. If you wait for the ideal time to start, it will never come. You are never too old to learn to play the piano, but you’ll never learn unless you decide to start. 11. Make practicing a priority If you don’t schedule a specific time to practice each day, you may find at the end of the day that you don’t have time to practice. If you want to learn to play the piano, commit yourself to applying what you learn and practicing regularly. Consistent practice in short sessions of time is better than practicing a lot all at once—for example, practicing every day for 30 minutes is more effective than practicing once a week for two hours. If you can, try to stick to a routine so practicing becomes a habit. As you practice, vary your techniques and the songs you play. This will keep you from getting bored and make practicing enjoyable. 12.	Playing Expressively Another distinct advantage that adults have over children is their desire to play piano expressively- something most kids don’t even remotely understand. While kids can learn to mimic the expressive qualities of a musical piece, only an adult can pour their emotions into a piece of music to effectively transfer emotion to the listener. You can learn to play more expressively using best piano tips resources. Dive into our free tips for learning piano and spend as much time as is possible practicing the techniques you’ll learn on our website, and you’ll discover something amazing happening over time- you will become the piano player you’ve always dreamed of being. Sign up for our free online piano course or get started now. 13.Practice slowly to avoid mistakes. Your brain will remember mistakes faster when you have an emotional outburst (“Arghhh, no”). Rather practice slowly and feed your brain the correct information, then give it positive affirmation like “Yeahhh, I’m a piano genius!” 14. Make a schedule to practice piano each week, start out with 15 minutes every other day (Though I bet it will turn out to be at least 30 once you start playing!) and work your way up to practicing every day! By setting easy goals, you can avoid associating practising piano with “pressure” or discomfort. Besides, your to-do list is long enough already. Playing piano should be the fun part of your week!And now you can add your piano practicing goals to a Google Calendar, which automatically finds the time to schedule your goals. 15. Be comfortable playing the piano piece before you move on to the next challenge. Learn to play the piece in time. Also try to play the piece by heart; that’s the best indication that you’re more than ready for the next song. Plus you’ll impress your listeners by not needing a musical score in front of you and hear them say, “Wow, he really IS a piano genius”.
